title: Function and Organization of Skeletal Muscle
content: Skeletal muscle is a collective group of muscles that contract to move bones. Different muscles have different orientations and responsibilities, some are meant to be antigravity and non-fatigable, while others provide power and propulsion. Muscle also pumps fluid up and down, stores amino acids, and regulates blood glucose. Each muscle is made up of billions of individual muscle fibers that contract and are surrounded by capillaries for nutrient exchange. The muscle fibers contain myonuclei which control the cell.

title: Skeletal Muscle Adaptability
content: Skeletal muscle is unique because it has an infinite number of nuclei spread throughout the muscle, giving it a lot of plasticity. The more nuclei a muscle has, the easier it is to respond to stressors, damage, and adaptations. Mitochondria are also important for producing cellular energy. Finally, the contractile units of muscle fibers are actin and myosin, which contract together and stack on top of each other, causing the muscle to gain height when flexed.

title: Muscle Fiber Types
content: Muscle fibers can be distinguished by their color or contractile speed. The red fibers have more capillaries, blood flow, and mitochondria, while the white fibers have less. Muscle fibers can also be categorized by their enzymatic differences. Red fibers are better at using aerobic metabolism, while white fibers are better at using glycolysis from the anaerobic part of the equation. Initially, there were two types of muscle fibers - Type I and Type II.

title: Gastrocnemius vs Soleus
content: The gastrocnemius and soleus muscles in the calf have different contractile properties. The soleus is slow to fatigue, while the gastrocnemius is fast to fatigue. Muscle fibers can be tested for their power output, allowing them to be distinguished by their contractile properties. This led to the nomenclature of fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers.

title: Muscle Fiber Types
content: Humans have three muscle fiber types (Type I, Type IIa, & Type IIx), while most other animals have four types (Type I, Type IIa, Type IIb, & Type IIx). Type I muscle fibers are less fatigable; they have more mitochondria but don’t produce as much force; they’re slower. As you move from Type IIA to Type IIx they become faster but more fatigable (because they are more reliant upon glycolysis and carbohydrate metabolism).

title: Soleus and Gastrocnemius Comparison
content: The gastroc in most humans is around 60-70% Type IIa fibers (maybe even up to 80%), and so they’re very, very fast. The gastroc will again cause a fast contraction, but they won’t hold on for very long, because they are fatigable. The soleus can be up to 90% slow-twitch. This is a great comparison, because most muscles in your body are some combination of fast- or slow-twitch, but the soleus and the gastroc are probably the best example of the two extremes.

title: Modifiability of Muscle Fiber Types
content: It is extremely trainable; it comes down to stimuli and time. The more stimuli you give it, and the more time you give it, the more it will change. If you are untrained, physically inactive, in a cast for two months, go into space flight ‒ responsiveness to training happens faster. If you are well-trained, as months and years go on, you start changing really, really slowly, because you are closer to the end of the spectrum. Functionally, there is no limit to how far you can go, given enough total exposure. To put some realistic numbers on the gastroc, in an untrained individual who hadn’t exercised for 5+ years, 8 weeks of exercise could cause 10-15% change in fiber type.

title: Muscle Fiber Type Transition
content: In humans, what more commonly happens is the current fiber type will transition its type. Remember there are three fiber types in humans; that’s not actually true either; there’s a whole combination of what we call hybrids.

title: Muscle Fiber Types
content: Muscle fibers can express Type I, Type IIa, and Type IIx fibers, and can be expressed in response to stimulus or lack thereof.

title: Hypertrophy
content: Hypertrophy is the process of muscle growth and involves changes in muscle fibers and underlying mechanisms.

title: Muscle Fiber Size
content: Fast-twitch fibers are generally larger than slow-twitch fibers, but training can change this. Classic endurance training results in fiber-type-specific hypertrophy, while strength training results in very large Type IIa fibers. Exogenous testosterone can also impact muscle fiber size.

title: Comparing Muscle Fibers
content: Comparing muscle fibers between individuals is challenging, but bodybuilders using exogenous testosterone will likely have larger muscle fibers than non-users. Powerlifters and bodybuilders have similar muscle fibers, but different from those of steady-state cyclists.

title: Hypertrophy Training
content: The process of muscle enlargement involves changes in muscle fibers and underlying mechanisms, but the exact causes are not fully understood.

title: Chronic Hypertrophy
content: Chronic hypertrophy refers to sustained muscle growth over time. Chronic hypertrophy is either going to be a result of either contractile hypertrophy or sarcoplasmic hypertrophy. In either case, the muscle cell got larger; the diameter is expanded. The question now is, what actually changed inside that cell that caused it, or allowed it to be permanently larger?

title: Sarcoplasmic Hypertrophy
content: In the case of sarcoplasmic hypertrophy, increases in metabolic enzymes and muscle tissue fluid occur. A contractile hypertrophy happens as a result of increasing proteins on those myosin and actin. That may or may not be important. For the myofilaments here, you don’t add more actin or myosin, you just add more protein, globulin to them and this increases their diameter.

title: Lattice Spacing
content: Lattice spacing is the spacing between actin and myosins; this is very, very important. As you put more proteins in the contractile units, the muscle fiber diameter need to increase to maintain optimal spacing [contractile hypertrophy]. This is probably the biggest explanation for why muscles increase in diameter.

title: Muscle Growth and Strength
content: Optimizing for muscle growth is not the same as optimizing for strength (and visa versa): at some point they will start to diverge, but at the very beginning they are tightly linked. As you continue with your training career, you get stronger and stronger, but the link between muscle size and strength starts to go away. It never goes away entirely because if you’re tacking on contractile units, it’s going to come with some increase in force (even if it’s not optimizing strength).

title: Sarcoplasmic Hypertrophy and Reps per Set
content: The bodybuilding community was proposing that higher repetition ranges produce sarcoplasmic hypertrophy, which is exclusively explained by increases in fluid retention. Further research showed that hypertrophy is pretty much equal anywhere between 5 reps to 30 reps per set. At the end of 30 reps, you need to be hurting as much as you would be at the end of 7. Higher reps are more time under tension and can be more taxing to your cardiovascular system.

title: Changes in Sarcoplasmic Hypertrophy with Years of Resistance Training
content: Mike developed technology to distinguish between cytoplasmic hypertrophy [sarcoplasmic hypertrophy] and contractile hypertrophy [myofibril number], and see how this changes over the course of training. His review paper shows a graph he’s developed that shows what happens over the course of your training experience. This shows changes in cytoplasmic hypertrophy [the green line below shows muscle fiber CSA, cross sectional area or volume] and contractile hypertrophy [the blue line below shows myofibril number] over years of training.

title: Training for Maximum Strength
content: Peter compiled a matrix of different athletes and training variable by comparing training of a powerlifter, an Olympic weightlifter, a Strongman, a bodybuilder, a CrossFit athlete, a track and field athlete in terms of training frequency, volume, and intensity (as a % of 1RM or VO2 max). Peter’s ultimate goal in doing this is to extract from each of these phenotypes how to train to be the best Centenarian Decathlete. In other words, Peter is training for the 90-year-old version of himself to be like a very fit 70-year-old. Powerlifting is explicitly a test of pure and absolute strength.

title: Peter's Deadlift Training
content: Peter deadlifted today, and the main set was four rounds of 1-minute, as many reps as possible with 315 lbs, with a 3-minute rest in between rounds. Andy notes, “You’ve got good leverage for pulling. You’ve got long arms. You’re probably pretty efficient at deadlifting.” Peter agrees, deadlifting was his best of the three powerlifting exercises, by far.

title: Powerlifting Training Principles
content: Peter has no desire to ever do a maximum rep deadlift, bench press or squat ever again. Instead, he’s interested in the principles of how powerlifters train. Andy distinguishes between what is theoretically optimal and what is technical optimal. Peter distinguishes these as efficacy versus effectiveness. Realistically, specificity is always the answer. If you want to get stronger, you should practice that movement pattern for 1-5 days per week; two days would be good for a lot of people.

title: Ideal Reps, Volume, and Load for Powerlifters
content: What do you recommend for the person who is willing to be in the weight room four days a week? Look into what’s called conjugate; there are many forms of this.

title: Westside Barbell Louie Simmons Conjugate Method
content: The Westside Barbell Louie Simmons form of conjugate is a little bit of pure strength work at the beginning, there’s a muscular endurance phase, there’s a speed phase, and it rotates through each week. They power through: bench, squat, deadlift, bench squat… One day you’re going to do a max deadlift and some assistance work in your low back/ glutes/ hamstrings/ etc. The next day, maybe it’s a max bench and work on your triceps/ shoulder/ rear delts/ neck/ etc. It’s a very easy model.

title: Specificity and Variation
content: Andy would stick mostly to the lift because specificity wins here. This person is not a professional athlete, so you can make the argument that they need more variation. Variation will give you a push toward overall safety because it’s less overuse of the same movement pattern and loading pattern. However the more variation there is, the less specificity. There is also less direct direct adaptation and less likelihood of overuse. For this person, the core of the day will focus on that exact movement ‒ a barbell back squat. This is the focus for 8 weeks prior to competition. On the off-season, he might introduce variation and do other stuff. In the specificity phase, you would focus on the primary lift and do a ton of accessories. If the hard work was focused on the barbell back squat, then maybe add a goblet squat, split squat, lateral lunges, reverse hypers, etc. For the accessories, use a higher repetition range not a max-effort set-up. “You might do sets of five, eight, something like that, to really support the joints and make everything feel good, but you’d keep your pure, pure strength work for that core lift.”‒ Andy Galpin

title: Reps and Force Production
content: Let’s pick the deadlift, for example. What’s the rep range you’re going to have them working in? Is there a number of reps that is so high that it’s getting you too far away from max strength? Five and less. When you get past five, you start losing force production. Are you recommending 5 reps at 85% of the 1RM? This depends a lot on fiber type and movement. The same is not true for a deadlift versus a bench. It’s a roughish number.

title: Prilepin's Chart and Velocity Transducers
content: The Prilepin chart (shown below) tells you how many total reps to do throughout the week at a given percentage of your 1RM. It give an idea of the max effort you can get away with and how much supporting work you need to do. To do this you need to know your 1RM. Velocity transducers can project your 1RM. Peter has a velocity transducer; it’s a device that sits on the ground and has a strap that goes on the bar. One example is Gym Aware. This will measure the speed of the exercise, you input the weight, and it tells you your projected 1RM based on the speed you’re doing the exercise and your level of fatigue. Peter finds it is less accurate with lower weight. But, it’s pretty accurate once you get into that five rep range.

title: Calculating 1RM
content: Is a velocity transducer accurate enough for someone who doesn’t want to do a 1RM? There are a number of online calculators to do a one-rep max test. Use a weight you’re comfortable with, and do it anywhere between 3-10 reps. The estimates that go up to 20 reps per set are not very accurate; so stay below 8 reps when you do this. Peter reflects, “You said something earlier that now I think kind of resonates. I have never found those calculators to work for me.” They’re not accurate for a slow-twitch guy. Andy notes, “Whatever you’re doing at your 85%, you’re doing 15 reps. I’m going to do four. I’m a super fast-twitch guy.” You also need to take into consideration your genetics and training history.

title: Working Sets
content: How many working sets do you need to do in a day?

title: The 3-5 Concept
content: In the beginning, you can maximize strength using the 3 to 5 concept: 3-5 days per week, 3-5 exercises at 3-5 reps per set, 3-5 total sets with 3-5 minutes rest between each set. This only works if you’re loading heavy; if you’re going light, it’s not going to work. If you go as low as 3 days per week, you’re going to do 3 exercises for 3 sets of 3; and the intensity will be high. If you go all the way to 5 days a week, 5 exercises, 5 sets of 5; that volume is going to be really taxing if your loading it appropriately under the powerlifting category.

title: Evaluating Intensity of Effort
content: RPE (rating of perceived exertion) and reps in reserve (RIR) are two ways to think about this. RPE is a scale of 6-20 (the original Borg scale); the top of the scale (20) is the hardest repetition you could ever do. If you use a scale of 1-5, 4 is probably the sweet spot. Reps in reserve is a similar idea; if you thought you could do 10 reps and you wanted to do 2 reps in reserve, you would stop at 8 reps (so there are 2 reps left in reserve). You would do a set of 4 and have 1 rep in reserve; so you get to the end of that 4 and maybe have 1-2 reps in reserve. Peter thinks that reps in reserve is easier to explain to people, but at the same time, you have to know what failure is. This is not something you can figure out by yourself. You have to have the experience of dropping a bar on your chest and having the guys run across the gym to pick it up. Andy suggests using a machine to safely determine RPE and RIR. People who are not highly trained fail epically when trying to determine RPE and RIR. People will think they are at a RIR of 2 but it is really more like a 7. People are way stronger than they realize. For the 3 to 5 system to work, are you aiming for 1-2 reps in reserve? Closer to 1 rep in reserve.

title: Maximizing Strength on Off Days
content: What do you advise powerlifters do on their off days if the objective is maximizing strength? Powerlifters are notorious for being lazy. If they’re not lifting one at max, they’re going to be circling Walmart for two and a half hours to get a closer parking spot. More recently, people in that community have started to realize the need for some level of fitness simply to handle the training volume. If you’re pouring sweat getting through your warmup and tying your shoes, you probably shouldn’t be doing one rep maxes all day. You need to get fit first. Andy’s advice: Do the training discussed and finish each workout with a set of 8-12; that little bit of volume will help to add fitness. To maximize strength, rest on the off days if you’re fit. Do recovery stuff, maintenance, mobility, breath work, Zone 2 or lower movement.

title: Preserving muscle glycogen and recovery
content: Preserving muscle glycogen is not a huge deal if you’re doing 3 sets of 3. But your nervous system requires carbohydrates for metabolism, and it takes time to recover. To restore muscle glycogen, phosphocreatine, and ATP.

title: Endurance work and weightlifting
content: As long as you have some baseline fitness, there is no reason it would give you an advantage to do more endurance work in-between days at the gym, lifting weights.

title: Powerlifting and recovery time
content: Powerlifters need recovery time because they are trying to put 1,000 pounds on their back. Even though both are 100% of your one-rep max, there’s an absolute load that is on a physical human body that does not scale, and that’s the major difference. That load just takes so much more rest than when you do your 70% and you can come back tomorrow and squat and be fine, because it was 220 pounds. That relativeness doesn’t scale.

title: Consequences of powerlifting on long-term health
content: Scientifically, there is no data on whether powerlifting has consequences on long-term health. Anecdotally, “I don’t think you would find a very highly competitive powerlifter who is under the illusion that this is great for their health”. It depends on how they train.

title: Defining Olympic weightlifting
content: Olympic weightlifting is a competition of who can lift the most amount of weight one time, and there are two exercises: the snatch and the clean and jerk has two parts but it’s one exercise.

title: Olympic Weightlifting
content: Olympic weightlifting is a test of maximum strength that involves the snatch and the clean and jerk. The weight lifted in both movements is added up to determine the winner. The snatch is the single highest power-producing exercise that has ever been studied. Olympic weightlifters are the most powerful athletes because they’re doing the most powerful movements. They have a wonderful combination of being really strong and really fast, and that’s why they produce so much power.

title: Training Principles of Olympic Weightlifting
content: To optimize for strength, Olympic weightlifters are not doing 12 reps; they’re doing less than 5 reps. The first step in training for Olympic weightlifting is to build the technical skills. There is a ton of technical work to learn these movements. Then, build strength doing exercises like front squats, push press, and overhead press. It takes time to develop the technical ability to get heavy enough on the snatch and clean and jerk. This is why a lot of folks will not use these movements. If someone is committed to investing 5 or 10 years, then it’s probably worthwhile because it’s total body.

title: Balance and Proprioception in Exercise
content: You’re jumping up and then down. Then, you’re catching yourself; this requires balance and proprioception.

title: Importance of Core in Overhead Squat
content: Your core has to be there for the overhead squat.

title: Economical Movement in Exercise
content: With the exception of horizontal pressing, it covers just about everything else, and so it’s a very economical, well-rounded movement.

title: Peak Concentric and Eccentric in Exercise
content: It’s peak concentric and eccentric because the amount of deceleration you have to do in that movement is insane. Whereas, in powerlifting, you don’t really get to test the eccentric phase to the same extent. There’s no landing, no absorption, no movement in space (which is very important for neural control and keeping your brain healthy).

title: Training Strategy for Olympic Weightlifting
content: He would put 135 on the bar as the max amount and do that as perfectly and quickly as possible. He would film himself to make sure elbow/ bar travel was perfectly straight. Then he would do insanely heavy front squats and shrugs and all sorts of other accessory movements.

title: Scaling of Weightlifting with Body Weight
content: A few people can manage triple their body weight. Realize that this doesn’t scale with size. For example, Lasha (the best guy on the planet for the last 6-8 years), he lifts about 265 kilos (585 lbs) and probably weighs 350 lbs; he’s never going to double his body weight. But the guys who are 140 lbs can get to three times their body weight.

title: Training for Weightlifting
content: We’re not going to load her up on the clean and jerk and on the snatch. She’s going to be using more weight than a PVC pipe and an empty bar. She’s using 10-pound bumpers for most of the time until we she gets that working just right. She’s using reps and sets based on the 3 to 5.

title: Peak Power Production in Exercise
content: Consider peak power production (the red line in the graph below). Force is how much load is on the bar. Plot force against velocity. At some point, if the load is too light, but very, very heavy, it’s not powerful. At the opposite end of the spectrum, the same thing happens. So where is the crossover point where there is enough velocity and enough mass? This is hyper-specific to the exercise.

title: Training for Compound Movements
content: For an exercise like a bench press or even a tricep extension, that’s probably going to happen at somewhere 30 to 40% of your one rep max. This is where you’ll have peak power. If you move to a more compound movement like a squat, instead of training at 30-40% of your peak, train at 40-50%.

title: Varying percentages of 1RM for peak power
content: If you go to a clean and jerk (or a snatch), that  number gets much higher (80-90%). A lot of folks won’t hit peak power in a snatch until they get to 90% of their max. If you do 90% of your 1RM on a bench press, you’re going to be moving super slow and you will not be producing any power. Maybe you’re going to hit peak power at 30-40% of your 1RM for the bench press, tricep press down, or bicep curl (a super low load). If you did a leg press, squat or deadlift it might be 40-50% of your 1RM. This also depends on the person.

title: Technical limitations and alternative exercises
content: This person is not going to get stronger from these exercises if there is a technical limitation. You may have to do a heavy kettlebell swing. Maybe you want to do an RDL (Roman deadlift), a deadlift, a step-up, or any number of exercises like that until they can get to a technical proficiency to where they can get 50, 60, 70% (or higher). You’re not really going to be truly testing strength because you’re still going to be super limited by technique, and you’re not at the peak power yet. Once you move to something insanely technical, you’ve got to get close got 80-90% of the 1RM. This is because of the nature of the exercise. The triple extension allows you to explode ‒ it’s an explosive hip, knee, and ankle extension. This will solely be limited by skill. You’ve got to go heavy before you’re getting to peak power, let alone peak strength.

title: Tracking power output when training
content: Peter uses power as the metric he’s training to. He’s able to see fall off and fatigue. Now he’s going to pay more attention to when he hits peak power (is it 50% of his 1RM?). Bryan Mann at the University of Miami has done a ton of great stuff on velocity-based training. There’s a training concept called cluster sets. Cluster sets are extremely effective because the quality of output (in power, velocity, etc.) is much higher. You reduce fatigue as compared to reps of 3, 4, or 5.

title: Cluster Sets for Pure Strength
content: In cluster sets, the aggregate quality, force output, and total achieved velocity is much higher so it’s very, very effective for pure strength; it may not be optimal for hypertrophy or other things.

title: Frequency of Training for Power Development
content: Because the load is low, you can do this every day. You’re talking about a small number of reps, not to fatigue (light weight). There’s no reason why you couldn’t do some power training every day. This is no different than playing a sport every day (basketball). Keep the training high quality.

title: Post-Activation Potentiation for Power Training
content: Peter recalls something he used to do that ties into both weightlifting and powerlifting. It was 2-4 reps of a heavy deadlift, and it was super setted with a plyometric (jump or drop) in between. There is science to support this experience; you’re referring to a phenomenon called post-activation potentiation. Fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers were discussed earlier.

title: Strongman vs Powerlifting vs Weightlifting
content: We are going from the highly specific powerlifter (where there are 3 exercises), to the weightlifter (where there are 2 exercises), to the Strongman where there is more breadth. You could argue that the Strongman is more functional, more versatile, and more engaging. At the outset Andy said the three things that mattered most were specificity, specificity, and specificity. When you’re dealing with something that has so many components, how do you wrap your mind around specificity versus generality? CrossFit has a very similar feel; you’re tested in a bunch of different planes.

title: Specificity in Strongman
content: There is still some specificity when you get into those competitions because they know which events they’re going to do. Someone who has optimized grip strength for holding atlas stones is not going to be the person who is optimized for the deadlift carry or overhead press. You’ll see people who win three straight events and they’ll get dead last in another one.

title: Training Principles of Strongman
content: The Strongman takes extremely heavy loads and does them to fatigue. They do it a little bit safer; you generally don’t see a bench press to fatigue (or deadlift). They do something like a car lift, and the reason is because you can actually load the bar a lot higher in the air. It becomes closer to a RDL (Roman deadlift). When you take that knee cross out of it, it allows you to do a lot more reps. They do a farmer’s carry as heavy as possible and drop it when they’re done, to hedge in that direction. A snatch (or a clean and jerk) is way to risky; they do a log press overhead. For a tire flip, you’re never fully lifting a 450 lb thing off the ground. The first movement of the deadlift, it might be 250 lbs that you’re lifting up. Then by the time you’re pushing it, you’ve got the momentum helping you. It’s infinitely safer. Your cardiorespiratory and muscular fatigue hit almost at the same time.

title: Advice for Someone New to Strongman
content: The next avatar ‒ how would you train a person who is new to this? A guy who has never powerlifted, never weightlifted, never done a Strongman. He goes to the gym and does a little bit of cardio and a little bit of strength training, but there’s never been specificity to the training. He doesn’t have any injuries that we need to worry about. Nothing is truly off limits, but he has no technique. He has no foundation of knowing what it’s like to deadlift at least twice his body weight. He thinks the Strongman competition would be fun and it’s inline with his health goals. But he doesn’t want to get injured, and he wants to be able to do this for quite some time. First, build a week of frequency and exercises you do throughout the week so you are not doing too many things too often in the same matter.

title: Andy’s advice for progression
content: Keep it below 10% progression per week. Start lower than you think. “In general, regardless of physical exertion, if you increase your total volume by more than 10% per week, you tend to start getting into problems.”‒ Andy Galpin

title: Measuring progress in Strongman training is difficult
content: In lifting, you can keep a tally of sets and reps per body part. How do you do that with a 100 lb medicine ball for 7 steps, versus a 50 lb medicine ball for 25 steps? They both hurt about the same. This is the problem exercise science has for comparing lifting to endurance.

title: Assessing training readiness
content: Peter used to look at resting heart rate in the morning and basically the willingness to train. Andy agrees, “It’s still the single best metric you can take”. Peter’s takeaway ‒ knowing how you feel the day of and listening is really important; if you do not feel like pushing yourself hard in the gym on a given day, that’s a really good sign that you shouldn’t. Give it until after the warmup phase before you make the decision and get on to the working sets. Just because you feel crappy doesn’t mean you don’t exercise that day; it’s a question of how hard are you going to push that day. Peter would argue, “There’s no day you shouldn’t be doing something”. This is where autoregulation training becomes awesome.

title: CrossFit
content: There is a pretty decent overlap between CrossFit and Strongman; these are events that take a really long time. There are certain sets that can take 20 minutes that are metabolically as demanding as what most people could barely do in an hour. CrossFit is a nice combination. There are some weightlifting movements. There is endurance; you might have to run/ cycle a marathon. You might see more circuit training, where you do as many rounds a you can in 10 minutes ‒ 20 kettlebell swings, plus 3 snatches, plus a vertical jump, plus 20 pull-ups.

title: CrossFit vs Strongman
content: Just like the Strongman, it’s not a single, structured exercise, it’s a combination of many exercises. Compared to Strongman, the absolute loads are lower. The volume of reps in a CrossFit competition tends to be way higher. Athletes in CrossFit are still very, very strong and powerful, but you won’t see anybody ever touch 600 lbs. Every Strongman is 600+ lbs; you might see 1,600 lbs. But you won’t see Strongman ever reach 65 reps in an exercise.

title: CrossFit vs Weightlifting
content: Similar to weightlifting in tech, CrossFit uses barbell movements. Big, complex movements. It’s similar to powerlifting in that sometimes max rep matters.

title: CrossFit vs Gymnastics
content: There are also a lot of gymnastics-based movements (hanging and pulling), and you’re going to get hammered if you’re over 200 lbs and you have to do 100 pull-ups in 5 minutes.

title: CrossFit Athletes
content: The avatar for a highly competitive male CrossFitter is 5’9” to 5’11”, 190-210 lbs. Gender and age are the only distinction you have in CrossFit. In CrossFit, you’re going to get punished for being heavier in some of the endurance events and punished for being lighter in some of the strength events.

title: CrossFit Misconceptions
content: The misconception about elite athletes in any of these categories is that they have done something that we have never seen before, it’s the fact that they’re just phenomenal athletes. CrossFitters are way more cardiovascularly fit than Strongman, and certainly way more than powerlifters and weightlifters. But you’re not going to find the average Crossfitter that has the same VO2 max as the average, equivalently high-level cyclist.

title: Cycling Training
content: Peter’s greatest regret in speaking about this stuff is that he has yet to come up with a way to explain what wattage feels like. When Bradley Wiggins absolutely smashed the one hour record (which is generally regarded as the most pain a human being can endure in any sport), he held 440 watts for one hour, crunched in a tuck position with his iliac vessels folded on top of each other. If you put the average person on a bike set to 440 watts, they’re going to be dead at 20 seconds. The average person might weigh 180 lbs, Bradley probably weighed 138 lbs (maybe 145). Wiggins was tall (probably 6’1”), but he looked like a bean pole, and the force he could generate for 60 minutes is more than you could generate for 30 seconds. Andy adds, 1,000 watts is a big, big number, but that wouldn’t be crazy for a cyclist to do in a 20-second burst. Further a cyclist could do that after riding for 6 hours at an average of 250 watts. Again, most people can’t hold 250 watts for 2 minutes. This is not suggesting that cycling training is great for power development, instead world-caliber athletes are good at a lot of things. A highly power-trained person could kick out 1,200/ 1,300 watts for sure.

title: CrossFit Athletes' Versatility
content: What makes CrossFit athletes special is how good they are at so many things.

title: Specificity in Training
content: Peter believes that specificity in training is crucial. He was a one-dimensional athlete when he was cycling, and his upper body was useless. He thinks this is true for all the athletes they’re talking about. Once you get into these Strongmen and CrossFit athletes though you start to see remarkable feats of strength and endurance across the great range. In some ways, this is more impressive.

title: The Importance of Baseline Aerobic Capacity
content: What is beautiful about CrossFit is you need to have a ton of baseline aerobic capacity. You need to have some peak power. You need to have some strength. You need to be highly anaerobic. You need to have real high recovery from anaerobic efforts. The most fascinating thing is, how do you train for this? Nobody had an answer. It’s just strategy.

title: Heart Rate Recovery as a Metric of Fitness
content: Heart rate recovery is a strong metric of fitness. Learning from elite athletes, heart rate recovery, V02 max, and other metrics.

title: VO2 Max Test and Heart Rate Recovery
content: There are places where you can get a VO2 max test done for around $100, and they’ll give you the 1-, 2-, and 3-minute heart rate recovery as well. The metrics we care about for the 30-, 60-, 120-second recovery is 80% in 2 minutes. If you’re above 80% after 2 minutes of recovery, sound the alarm ‒ this is a big problem; walk yourself down.

title: VO2 Max and vVO2 Max
content: VO2 max is not correlated with speed. In running, vVO2 max matters more than VO2 max. In cycling, VO2 max is not nearly as important a pVO2 max (power at VO2 max).

title: Predictors of Endurance
content: In the running literature, there are 3 main components that are going to predict endurance: 1 – VO2 max, 2 – Running economy, 3 – Lactate threshold. VO2 max is only one of these. Andy predicts that movement economy on a bike is probably similar. It’s probably your power ratio. Peter adds, FTP to weight is important.

title: Max Heart Rate and VO2 Max as Predictors of Performance
content: You are not going to find max heart rate to be a predictor of performance. The same is true for VO2 max, people stop before their actual max. When most people get to 98%, they have seconds of life before they’re gasping for something. Andy has had a lot of high-level athletes, very fit championship fighters who have a max heart rate of 172-175. His VO2 max is not particularly high relative to these things.

title: Factors to Pay Attention to in Terms of Accuracy and Measure
content: When heart rate gets too high, you start limiting time to fill. Your preload is low and your stroke volume goes down. It’s not always the best thing to be super high. There are some other factors to pay attention to in terms of accuracy and measure.

title: Lifelong Athletes
content: These guys were lifelong athletes; they were world champions in the 40s and 50s and never stopped. Their average max heartbeat at their age was 150, 148. Their VO2 maxes are probably still in the mid-30s. Several of them age 86, 88 had a VO2 max of over 40.

title: Optimizing for Being a Well-Rounded Athlete
content: Peter thinks of all the athletes discussed, the CrossFit athlete in some ways is the most representative of our long-term goal. Let’s assume you’re optimizing for being the most well-rounded athlete, not a spike in one domain over another. The number to aim for is 70, 20, 10. 70% of the time you’re in the gym is for practice. 20% of the time, you’re going to compete. 10% of the time, you’re basically going to death.

title: Balancing High-Intensity Workouts
content: One big problem we see with people that also have real jobs, is how much time they spend in sympathetic drive. They end up just torching themselves. It’s too much high intensity too often, and they don’t understand when to dial it back. In this model, 2 days a week, you’re working out, blood pumping, feeling good; in recovery, you’re going to feel great. Only 1 day a week are you going to push it harder. Then only 1 of those days in 4 weeks are you going to push really, really, really hard. That’s enough for most people that have other life stressors. You’ll be able to recover from that. You’ll also feel that you’re getting something out of your training.

title: The Importance of Allostasis in Training
content: Andy has his own algorithm that he uses to factor in everything, visible and hidden stressors, into a training program. Adaptation in the body happen because of stress, but that stress bucket can be overfilled. What you want to do is fill that bucket with the type of stress you want, and dump out as much of the stress that you don’t want. If you’re already pre-filled with other stuff, and then you add a little bit of training stress, you start overfilling this bucket.

title: Training for Peak Speed and Velocity
content: Sprinters need to be strong because they have to overcome force for a 100- or 200-meter dash. They have to have true elite speed, which is a function of how fast you can turn your feet over in running, as well as stride length. To train for peak speed, target strength and peak velocity using light resistance, 30% or less. To train for peak velocity, use normal or overspeed training. Speed training and power training are almost identical. You can do them at a very high frequency. You want to do complex movements. For the most part, physiological fatigue is low. It’s low volume, high quality. You’re going lighter so you can move faster.

title: Comparison of Fatigue in Different Types of Training
content: There’s not fatigue really, no joint beat up. This is in contrast to CrossFit training. CrossFit has the most systemic fatigue associated with it because you’re doing high-intensity stuff so often. CrossFit is whole muscle, cardiovascularly driven, there’s a massive endocrine response. Training for the other athletes discussed is pretty much localized. Strongman might have some systemic fatigue.

title: Neurological Component of Powerlifting, Weightlifting, and Sprinting
content: In powerlifting, more in weightlifting, and certainly in true speed stuff with the sprinter, there is such a high component to neural activation. We need to make sure that we’re optimize all the motor units we need. And in the case of speed, you have to do it in the right sequence. Movement mechanics, being smooth, and having the rhythm to move fast is very, very challenging. This is called synchronization ‒ you have to fire the right muscles in the right group, in the right order, throughout your gait while running. This is not necessary in powerlifting because everything is on maximally. You’ll commonly hear sprinters say, “You got to be in the right rhythm”. You might get faster without actually improving your velocity ability by just getting in better rhythm. This means learning what to fire, what to relax, so a joint can move, and then be ready to strike again, and again. It can be both autonomic and conscious. The idea would be to make this as subconscious as possible, so in the moment you’re relaxed and moving. Initially when you learn it, it’s going to be very conscious.

title: Training for Maximum Speed
content: What is the most taxing workout that the sprinter is doing during the week? What is the workout from which they need a recovery? True peak speed stuff. If you’re trying to train maximum speed, and you’re 5% slower tomorrow, then we’re not trying maximum speed anymore. To hit a new peak velocity, the level of recovery has to be higher. It’s not that you’re super sore, generally you’re going to feel fine. But your numbers are 3% slower, and you know you’re not recovered enough.

title: Training for the Centenarian Athlete
content: Let’s now tie this all together for a totally different type of athlete: the centenarian athlete. We’re not starting with people who were world-class Olympic cross-country skiers in their 20s who never stopped. We’re talking about somebody in their 40s who has the epiphany that says, “Wait a minute, it’s cool to be a powerlifter. It’s cool to be a weightlifter. It’s cool to be a CrossFitter, a Strongman, an elite runner, cyclist, swimmer, whatever, but I’m going to pick a different sport. I’m going to pick a sport where the optimization is around my ability to be as physically robust as possible in the last decade of my life, which means I want to be able to do a bunch of things that most people can’t even fathom when they’re 80 or 90 years old.” One of the biggest trade-offs you have to make is optimizing against getting injured. Because the compounding effect of training is so strong that it’s rivaled only by the compounding effect of not training. “You will lose it way faster than you will gain it, and therefore, you could argue rule number one of what I’m proposing is, you can’t ever stop training”‒ Peter Attia. What would we take from training for each of these phenotypes into our centenarian decathlon? Let’s work backwards, beginning with physiology. There are 3 things you need to train, and you can mix and match from any of those areas. 1 – High-quality functioning muscle. 2 – Nervous system (peripheral and central), our motor control needs to be very, very astute.

title: Importance of Variation in Physical Activity
content: The lack of variation and range of motion in powerlifting can be problematic for brain health. Proprioceptive innervation is important for maintaining brain function throughout life, which requires movement in space and learning. Physical activity that is uncontrolled, such as outdoor hiking or sports like surfing and badminton, is necessary to engage with the environment and have non-uniform steps and terrain. Strongman and Olympic weightlifting are examples of physical activities that require reacting to the world.

title: High Force Production
content: High force production is necessary to preserve nerves by asking all the motor units to work. Something throughout the week should be high force production, such as powerlifting, weightlifting, Strongman, or CrossFit. This should be > 80% of your max.

title: Cardiovascular Health
content: The cardiovascular system needs to sustain consistent work output over a minimum of 30 minutes with no interval or break. This can be achieved through activities like an Air Bike, sled push, jog, or swim. It is also important to get to max heart rate at least once a week, which can be achieved through CrossFit, Strongman, or powerlifting. Recovery from high-intensity exercise is also important.

title: Weekly Plan for Physical Activity
content: A weekly plan for physical activity should include one day of playing an uncontrolled activity/sport, one day of high-force production, one day of max heart rate, and one day of sustained heart rate. These can be combined into a 40-minute workout that includes strength training, playing pickleball, max strength training, and a CrossFit/20-minute AMRAP.

title: Muscular Health
content: Muscular health requires sufficient strength and size, with a minimum requirement as we age. ALMI (appendicular lean mass index) and FFMI (fat free mass index) are used to measure muscular health, with above average or higher being ideal. Debunking the myth that too much muscle mass is detrimental to health as you age, the literature suggests that strength trumps size.

title: Exploring Exercise Myths
content: In part 3, Peter Attia will explore the myth that strength is paradoxically harmful as you age and that strength athletes struggle with age. The uncoupling of size and strength is highly correlated with longevity, with the literature suggesting that strength trumps size. The argument that size matters goes back to the non-structural component of muscle, the metabolic component.

title: Muscle as a Glucose Reservoir
content: We can never lose sight of the fact that muscle is our greatest glucose reservoir, and the metabolic benefits of having a huge glucose sink are enormous.

title: Importance of Muscular Endurance
content: Muscular endurance is also important for walking up 15-20 steps. You need to be able to do something for 20 repetitions in a row. This is not going to be cardiovascularly limited, but limited by local muscular endurance and strength.

title: Strength to Weight Ratio and Fatigue
content: The strength to weight ratio factors into fatigue. People think there is a J-shaped curve of too much muscle mass as you age being linked to higher mortality when in reality, it’s a U-shaped curve.

title: Avoiding Exercise-Induced Injuries
content: Exercise-induced injuries happen in a couple of ways. Rarely is muscle the problem. The only reason joints really get hurt is repetition over bad movement patterns. You need to move properly to keep connective tissue and joints integrated.

title: Tips for Avoiding Injury
content: The only problem you have with the cardiopulmonary system or cardiovascular system is systemic fatigue. So, if you’re not overdoing it globally, then you won’t feel rundown or get sick often. Andy Galpin suggests starting with perfecting movement patterns, then loading them very specifically. Once you’ve mastered it with two limbs, then you can look into doing it unilaterally.

title: Functional Movement
content: When you add volume on top of dysfunctional movement, what do you expect to happen in week 6? Good form will allow you to move perfectly well both eccentrically and concentrically. You want to be able to do it in both a bilateral and unilateral position. You want to be able to do it with load. You want to be able to go fast. You want to go through a variety of movement positions ‒ overhead pressing, overhead pulling, horizontal pressing and pulling, lower body hinging, lower body pressing, rotational, unilateral support, diagonal.

title: Cardiovascular System
content: Improving the cardiovascular system first is a good strategy. There is data to suggest that 45-minutes of steady state endurance training (such as cycling) before hypertrophy training (aka strength training) results in more muscle growth. So being in good aerobic fitness is quite powerful and important, even if you’re trying to get muscle mass. In that study, was it because the cycling trained group had a higher work capacity when they were doing the hypertrophy training? Andy recalls that the total workload accomplished was the same, but he would have to look at this study again (he might be wrong).

title: Injuries
content: One of the injuries Peter sees a lot is a torn Achilles. This seems to happen to the athlete who has been inactive for a while, then he goes right back to that indoor soccer match and boom, it’s so loud you can hear it across the gym. This occurs when you ask connective tissue (the Achilles tendon) to do maximum contraction on a hyper loaded eccentric stop and change when it’s never contracted more than 50% of it’s max for years. You’re going to tear something somewhere. It’s probably not going to be an ACL, the Achilles is going to go first. In pro sports it’s the opposite, the Achilles is going to handle the load and the ACL will tear first. This is easy to avoid with some tissue tolerance, which is a fancy way of saying expose that tissue to demand slowly, and slowly increase the demand over time. One thing Peter finds is great for this is warming up with some sort of jumping. Especially as he is getting older. It’s multiplanar. It’s simple back and forth, side to side, and then one leg out. Like doing the clock, one o’clock, two o’clock, three o’clock, four o’clock, five o’clock, and by five and six o’clock, you’re actually having to spin yourself backwards, and you’re always coming back to the center of the clock, if that makes sense. These aren’t huge jumps. The goal is to introduce lower leg variability and tension with the tendons and connective tissue at unusual angles. This is why Andy is now more of a proponent of running for health than he used to be. Initially he was apprehensive because of the high rate of injury from running. But now he has changed his thoughts on that because a small amount of running is enough to keep tissue tolerance through most of the lower half. A few miles a week; a normal human should be able to run a mile. A little bit of sprinting in the straightaways is good too; do two laps and walk the corners. This will help you stay away from a lot of foot- and Achilles-related injuries.
